snippet: While the Supreme Court will decide this week whether to take another look at the Citizens United decision, critics warn about its growing fondness for unsigned majority opinions.
abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column predicts that the Supreme Court, which will decide whether to take a second look at the Citizens United campaign finance decision, will most likely issue an unsigned majority opinion to reverse a recent lower court decision defying the original ruling; notes that many critics warn that this tool, which has become a favorite of the Court, is problematic because it resolves cases without adequate information and deliberation, and is done so anonymously.
lead_paragraph: While the Supreme Court will decide this week whether to take another look at the Citizens United decision, critics warn about its growing fondness for unsigned majority opinions.

headline.main: Mystery of Citizens United Sequel Is Format, Not Ending
